fileDesc.extent: Approx. 8 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 3 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

notesStmt.note: Transcribed from: (Early English Books Online ; image set 23584)
Images scanned from microfilm: (Early English books, 1475-1640 ; 1719:12)
Title and imprint suggested by STC (2nd ed.).
First words of text: hic & hec & hoc intercus.
Imperfect: lacks all but signatures C2 and C3.
Reproduction of original in the St. John's College (University of Cambridge). Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Latin language -- Grammar -- Early works to 1500.

revisionDesc.change: 2009-05 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2009-12 Mona LogarboText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p:
hic & hec & hoc interrus. & eſt doctrina & nō exceptio. Dant hec ſi creſcant gtūs et v ſibi ſeruet Dicit auctor ꝙ nōia tercie declinatioīs termīata in vs habentia gtm̄ ſuꝑantem. in cuiꝰ penultima hec vocalis v retineat
ur . ſunt generis fe. vt hec ſalus ſalutis & hec virtus virtutis.

Hoc monoſillaba dant vt thus ſed dr̄
h hic grus Hic dat & h hic tibi ſus epychenū dat genꝰ Dicit ꝙ nōia tercie declinacōis ter. in vs hic mus vniꝰ ſillabe ſunt ge. neu. vt hoc thus. ſed gruseſt ge. fe. ſus vero cōis ge. mus autem genus ꝓmiſcui. etiam declinat
ur ꝑ h hic vocabula expoſita ſunt ſupra. hi format Eſt pecꝰ h hic pecudis pecꝰ hoc pecoris ti Dicit ꝙ pecus pecudis eſt ge. fe. & pecus pecoris neu. venꝰ eris. ꝑus eſt ge. neu. & indeclina bile. drā eorū p • s̄. Quarte nom̄ in vs mari
bus ſociare ſolemꝰ Dicit auctor ꝙ nōia quarte declinationis ſunt ge. maſ. vt h hic viſus auditus fructus currus Hic ꝯp̄hendunt
ur infinita nōia v
er balia in vs. que regulariter formant
ur ab vitimis ſupinis v
er borū. vt a video viſus us ui. a rideo ris;us us ui. a fluo fluxus us ui. Ab audio auditus us ui. ab haurio hauſtus us ui. a colo cultus us ui. a fruor fructus us ui. a gradior greſſus us ui &c.. Item ꝯtinent multa nōia in • atus dignitatem ſignificantia. vt A papa papatus us ui A cardinalis cardinalatus us ui Ab ep̄s ep̄atus us ui A decanus decanatꝰ us ui A doctor doctoratꝰ A mgr̄ mgrātꝰ A baccalariꝰ baccalariatꝰ A ſcriba ſcribatꝰ A dux ducatꝰ A miles militatꝰ A ſcabinus ſcabinatus. & ſic de alijs.

Hec acꝰ at
que tri
bus & porticꝰ & manꝰ idꝰ Hec anꝰ & pinꝰ nurꝰ ſocrꝰ & domꝰ add • Hic hec hoc ve ſpecꝰ illi penꝰ aſſocietur Hic ponit exceptionē a regula p̄dicta dicens. ꝙ nōia in littera poſita licet fint quarte declinationis tamen ſunt ge. fe. vt hec anus .i. vetula. hec tribus .i. ꝓgenies. hec porticus eſt ꝑ quam ſit introitus. hec manus. hec ydus id eſt diuiſio temꝑis ꝓpe ſunt dies octo cuiuſlibet mensꝭ hec acus. hec pinus. hec nurus. hec domus. hec ſocrus. Deinde dicit. ꝙ ſpecus poteſt eſſe ge. maſ. vel fe. ſil •
̄ & penus. vnde Acus eſt qua fuit quarte Sed tercie Acus aceris eſt palea Pinꝰ eſt nomen arboris Nurus eſt vxor filij Socrus eſt mater vxoris vel mariti Specus eſt foramen inde ſpelunca.
Cū nom̄ ſit in aus hec illi iūgitur vt laus Dicit ꝙ nōia terminata in aus diphtho • gū ſunt ge. fe. vt hec laus.
S • vult hec iungi ſi conſona preſidet illi Dicit ꝙ nōia terminata in s p̄cedente ꝯſonante ſunt ge. fe. vt hec plebs puls hyems mens daps pars.

Adiectiua notes qi
bus ōne genꝰ dare debes Hic ponit excep. dicens. ꝙ adiectia dn̄t excipi. qr ſūt ge. ōis. vt h hic & hec & hoc ſapiēs. dens qo
que quadrās Mons pōs fons h hic dant mars ſeps ſtirps Dicit auctor ꝙ nōia in littera poſita ſunt ge. maſ. vt h hic mons montis. hic fons fontis. h hic mars martis .i. deus belli. h hic ſepsē ſerpēs. h hic ſtirpsē trūcꝰ arboris. hec ſtirps eſt ꝓgenies. h hic quadrans quadrantis eſt inſtrumentum
ad ſciendum horas diei.

Et partes aſſis torrens ſociabitur iſtis At
que chalybs. Quod gens eſt ſiue metallum. Dicit auctor ꝙ partes aſſis ſicut quincuns &c̄. & hoc nomen torrens generale fluiorū iungit
ur
p̄dictis. Vlterius ſciendū ꝙ as aſſis eſt pondus duodecim vnciarū. Et ſi inde remouet
ur vnū. illud vnum qd remouet
ur
dr vncia. & illa vndecīm q̄ remanent dicunt
ur denus .i. vndecim vncie Preterea ſi remouent
ur duo. illa duo dempta ab aſſe dicū tur ſecuns. quaſi ſexta ꝑs aſſis. ſed illa decem q̄ rema nent dicunt
ur decuns .i. decem vncie. Preterea remouent
ur tria ab aſſe remanent nouē. & illa tria dempta dicuntur q̄drans q̄ſi ꝑta ꝑs aſſis. & illa nouem que remanent dicunt
ur dodrans. & interp̄tat
ur nouem Si remouent
ur ab aſſe q̄tuor remanēt octo. & illa q̄tuor remota dicunt
ur triens q̄ſi tercia ꝑs aſſis. & dr a tris qd eſt tres Vnde triens p̄ mo ſignificat tres: & ex ꝯſequenti q̄ttuor: qr quattuor ſunt tercia ꝑs aſſis. & illa octo q̄ remanēt dicunt
ur biſſe Et interp̄tat
ur biſſe octo. & eſt grecū Preterea ſi remouētur ab aſſe
qui n
que remanēt ſeptem. & illa
qui n
que remota dicunt
ur
qui ncuns a quin
que . & illa ſeptem q̄ remanent dicūt
ur ſeptuns a ſeptem Preterea ſi remouent
ur ab aſſe ſex illa ſex dicunt
ur ſemis. & illa ſex q̄ remanēt ſilr̄ dicunt
ur ſemis Et dr ſemis de ſemis qd eſt dimidius. & as aſſis q̄i dimidia ꝑs aſſis Et ita patet q̄ ſunt ꝑtes aſſis. Torrens torrentis ē fluuiꝰ vel aq̄ veniens cū impetu & imbribus repētina magnū hn̄s incrementū. ſed adueniēte eſtate calore ſolis torreſcit areſcit & deſiccat
ur Vn̄ ꝓpheta Cōuerte dn̄e captiuitatē nr̄am ſicut torrens in auſtro Chalybs fluuiꝰ ē hyſpanie iux̄ quē populi īhabitāt dicti chalybes
apud quos ſunt minere ferri optimi quas nudi illi laborantes effodiunt. Similiter & alij eodem nōie cognōiati ſunt populi iuxta paphlagoniā in ponto & amazoni
bus ꝯtermini. & capitur plerū
que chalybs ꝓ ipſa ferri maſſa Nonnun
quam vero ꝓ inſtrumento ex chalybe ꝯfecto. Dant hic ps iūcta poliſillaba ſꝪ variātur Hic auth forceps & adeps ſꝪ s hic ſeps Dicit ꝙ nōia terminata in s p̄cedente p ſunt ge. maſ. poliſillaba .i. pluriū ſillabarū. vt hic anceps Sed forceps ideſt inſtrumentū capiendi ferrū & adeps variant
ur ꝑ hic aut hec. ideſt ſunt generis incerti Sed hoc nomen ſeps ꝓ ſerpente eſt generis maſculini Inuenit
ur etiam hec ſeps ꝓ quo dicit
ur ſepes ſepis.

Plura
que dāt h hic & h hic celebs īfāſ
que parēſ
que Protulit ouidius infancia detulit ora Et pinceps effrons illi coniūge bifrontem Dicit auctor ꝙ plura reꝑiunt
ur in cōmuni genere declinata. vt h hic & hec celebs .i. caſtus h hic & hec infans h hic & hec parens h hic & hec pinceps h hic & hec effrons .i. ſine fronte hic & hec anceps. ideſt dubius.

Hec x p̄ponas ſed plurima demere debes In hac parte auctor determinat de generi
bus noīm terminatorū in x Et dicit ꝙ nōia in x terminata ſunt ge. fe. vt lex legis Deinde dicit ꝙ plura debent excipi. & facit exceptionem.
An triplici genere decet adiectiua notare Dicit ꝙ adiectiua in x terminata ſunt ge. ōnis. vt h hic et hec & hoc felix.
